change.li: $Log: encyclopedia.xml,v $ Revision 1.28 2006/03/27 14:02:23 gcrane more refinements Revision 1.27 2006/03/26 04:13:20 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.26 2006/03/25 19:26:47 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.25 2006/03/25 16:38:06 gcrane Did a lot of work to clean up the base headers for subentries. These should more often now only include global descriptions, e.g, PERSON, son of A stays, but PERSON, fought at Troy goes. --> "Fought at Troy" can be one of many events and is not a global identifier Revision 1.24 2006/03/20 19:15:42 gcrane cleaned up the formatting Revision 1.23 2006/03/20 14:15:22 gcrane small changes Revision 1.20 2006/03/18 15:34:36 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.19 2006/03/18 01:14:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.18 2006/03/17 23:55:18 gaweaver small fixes Revision 1.17 2006/03/17 21:56:39 gaweaver Calliopi From Antiphon until Chilon Revision 1.16 2006/03/17 15:39:04 gaweaver no message Revision 1.15 2006/03/10 00:01:20 gaweaver changes made by GRC while over the atlantic Revision 1.14 2006/03/05 03:47:42 gcrane base file Revision 1.13 2006/03/04 13:13:03 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.12 2006/03/03 18:21:05 gaweaver Agenor (10) Revision 1.11 2006/02/15 16:24:46 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.10 2006/02/13 21:52:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.9 2006/02/13 01:57:42 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.8 2006/02/12 23:12:05 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.7 2006/02/12 15:30:08 gcrane major structural update: the descriptive info has now been moved up into the headers and id's added to div1 type="entry" Revision 1.6 2006/02/12 13:23:59 gcrane moved descriptions up into the header: the goal is to make the header more informative and thus to facilitate the mechanics of aligning entries in this list with those in Smith's etc Revision 1.5 2006/02/11 19:49:21 gcrane more small fixes to make the coding consistent Revision 1.4 2006/02/11 18:50:04 gcrane working towards moving identifiers for all entities up into the subentry HEAD Revision 1.3 2006/02/10 22:43:14 gcrane changed the structure so that every entry has a subentry -- this simplifies the structure (i hope) Revision 1.2 2005/08/18 13:53:45 packel item tags... Revision 1.1 2005/07/25 14:32:52 packel Converted to XML Revision 1.34 2003/07/01 22:16:05 yorkc Updated texts to TEI P4 and Perseus P4 extensions; minor cleanup (esp. character encodings and typos.) Revision 1.33 2000/03/16 03:17:12 dasmith Gave homonym entries a top-level header. Revision 1.32 2000/03/16 02:52:18 dasmith Added alphabetic letter DIV0s. Made entries subordinate to alphabetic letters in refsDecl. Revision 1.31 2000/03/15 15:12:45 amahoney make homonyms sub-entries Revision 1.30 2000/03/14 18:11:05 amahoney several more random issues, but the Apollodorus refs really are right now Revision 1.27 2000/03/04 20:34:25 dasmith Added separate funder entity to TEI header. Revision 1.26 2000/02/22 17:17:30 amahoney fix bibl refs to known works Revision 1.25 2000/02/04 17:58:05 dasmith Primary lookup by ID (mostly useful for internal navigation). Revision 1.24 2000/01/10 21:09:41 acsmith trying again to change pilaster def. Revision 1.23 2000/01/10 20:16:54 dasmith Fixed sentence grammar. Revision 1.22 1999/10/01 14:11:04 acsmith Amy did away with dangling ref. to Type A2 cup, and turned all Type A1 cups into Type A cups, and lower cased type in Proto type A cup. Revision 1.21 1999/09/30 21:52:22 dasmith Fixed amphorae cross-refs. div3.p: A form of early construction, the technique involved planting posts in the ground through which were intertwined branches, twigs, grass, etc. which was then "daubed" or covered with mud to hold the intertwined materials in place.

div2.subhead: works and Days, only genuine work of Hesiod according to Boeotians of Helicon

div3.p: In one sense, group refers to a list of vases which have common elements, yet cannot be assigned to a specific vase painter. In the sense we use group, it refers to a group of painters whose work/style is similar, and in this respect, group is almost synonymous to workshop. These painters may have worked side-by-side or may have simply been contemporaries. The question that arises is how directly one painter influenced another. Workshop is used to define a direct working relationship between painters and can be used with certainty when it is known that two painters collaborated on painting a single vase. It is probable that many groups actually represented workshops, but it is very difficult to prove.

div2.subhead: wreaths, of corn worn by children and afterwards laid up in sanctuary of Artemis
